content.title: Cardiac Biomarkers
content.summary: Cardiac biomarkers are blood-based molecules used to diagnose, risk-stratify, and monitor cardiac diseases. High-sensitivity troponin (hs-cTn) is the gold standard for myocardial infarction diagnosis. BNP and NT-proBNP are used for heart failure diagnosis and prognosis. Understanding kinetics and non-cardiac causes of elevation is essential for interpretation.
key_points: High-sensitivity troponin I or T: gold standard for MI diagnosis
Troponin elevation requires rise/fall pattern + clinical context for MI diagnosis
BNP/NT-proBNP: heart failure diagnosis, prognostication, and treatment monitoring
BNP <100 or NT-proBNP <300 pg/mL makes acute HF unlikely (high NPV)
Many non-cardiac causes of troponin elevation exist (renal failure, sepsis, PE)
CK-MB largely replaced by troponin; may help detect reinfarction timing
content.statement: Cardiac biomarkers including high-sensitivity troponin for myocardial injury and natriuretic peptides for heart failure are essential diagnostic and prognostic tools, requiring understanding of kinetics, cutoffs, and non-cardiac causes of elevation.

explanation.intuition: When heart muscle is damaged, it releases proteins into the bloodstream like a cracked container leaking its contents. Troponin leaks from injured heart cells; natriuretic peptides are released when the heart is stretched from volume/pressure overload. These blood tests are like 'smoke detectors' for cardiac problems.
explanation.key_insight: Troponin elevation alone does not equal MI - it indicates myocardial injury. The 4th Universal Definition of MI requires clinical evidence of ischemia PLUS rise/fall pattern. Chronic troponin elevation (stable levels) suggests chronic injury (heart failure, renal failure) rather than acute MI.
explanation.technical_details: High-sensitivity troponin assays detect levels 10-100x lower than conventional assays, enabling earlier MI detection. The 99th percentile URL is the diagnostic threshold. Natriuretic peptides are cleaved from proBNP: BNP is the active hormone (cleared by NPR-C and neprilysin); NT-proBNP is inactive and renally cleared.

definitions_glossary.troponin: Cardiac structural protein released during myocyte injury; I and T subtypes
definitions_glossary.high_sensitivity_troponin: hs-cTn; assay detecting very low troponin concentrations
definitions_glossary.99th_percentile_URL: Upper reference limit defining elevated troponin
definitions_glossary.rise_and_fall_pattern: Dynamic troponin change indicating acute myocardial injury
definitions_glossary.BNP: Brain natriuretic peptide; released from ventricular myocytes with stretch
definitions_glossary.NT_proBNP: Inactive N-terminal fragment of proBNP; renally cleared
definitions_glossary.myocardial_injury: Elevated troponin from any cause (ischemic or non-ischemic)
definitions_glossary.type_2_MI: MI from supply-demand mismatch (tachycardia, hypotension, anemia)
definitions_glossary.CK_MB: Creatine kinase MB isoenzyme; less specific than troponin
definitions_glossary.acute_coronary_syndrome: Spectrum including STEMI, NSTEMI, unstable angina

troponin.release_mechanism: Myocyte necrosis, membrane damage, or active release

kinetics.onset: Detectable 1-3 hours after injury with hs-cTn
kinetics.duration: Elevated for 5-14 days depending on infarct size

natriuretic_peptides.stimulus: Wall stretch from volume or pressure overload

criteria: Detection of rise and/or fall of cTn with at least one value above 99th percentile URL
Plus clinical evidence of myocardial ischemia (symptoms, ECG changes, imaging evidence, or angiographic evidence)

serial_testing.0_1h_algorithm: Baseline + 1h troponin; rule-out if both low without significant change

acute_HF_diagnosis.BNP: <100 pg/mL: HF unlikely; >400 pg/mL: HF likely
acute_HF_diagnosis.NT_proBNP: <300 pg/mL: HF unlikely; >900 pg/mL (age 50-75) or >1800 (>75): HF likely

differential_diagnosis: Cardiac vs non-cardiac cause of troponin elevation
Heart failure vs other dyspnea causes (using BNP/NT-proBNP)

interpretation_guides_therapy.elevated_troponin_without_ischemia: Identify and treat underlying cause (type 2 MI, myocarditis, etc.)
interpretation_guides_therapy.chronic_stable_elevation: Reflects underlying cardiac disease; not indication for ACS therapy

BNP_guided_therapy.evidence: GUIDE-IT trial did not show benefit of BNP-guided therapy over usual care
BNP_guided_therapy.current_use: Diagnosis, prognosis, and assessing response to therapy

definition.@value: Blood-based molecules including troponin and natriuretic peptides used to diagnose, risk-stratify, and monitor cardiac diseases

scopeNote.@value: Covers troponin for MI diagnosis, natriuretic peptides for heart failure, kinetics, and interpretation pitfalls

learning_objectives: Apply the 4th Universal Definition of MI using troponin criteria
Interpret troponin values using rise/fall pattern and clinical context
Use BNP/NT-proBNP to diagnose and risk-stratify heart failure
Identify non-cardiac causes of troponin elevation
Distinguish Type 1 from Type 2 MI based on mechanism
clinical_pearls: Elevated troponin â‰  MI; requires rise/fall PLUS clinical evidence of ischemia
Stable chronically elevated troponin (renal failure, HF) does not indicate acute MI
BNP <100 or NT-proBNP <300 has >95% NPV for ruling out acute HF
Obesity falsely lowers BNP; renal failure falsely elevates NT-proBNP
hs-cTn detects earlier but also detects more non-ACS causes of elevation
common_misconceptions: Any troponin elevation is a heart attack - type 2 MI and non-ischemic injury are common
Normal troponin at presentation rules out MI - serial testing needed
CK-MB is still first-line - troponin has replaced it as gold standard
